items.def: Seven-layer conceptual framework defining network communication functions: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, Application.
Four-layer practical model for internet communications: Network Access, Internet, Transport, Application. Basis of modern networking.
Network connecting devices in limited geographical area (building, campus). High speed, low latency, privately owned.
Network spanning large geographical areas connecting multiple LANs. Lower speed, higher latency, often using carrier services.
Logical segmentation of physical network creating isolated broadcast domains. Improves security and performance.
Network segment isolating public-facing services from internal network. Contains web servers, mail servers, FTP. Buffer zone.
Dividing network into smaller segments to improve performance, security, and management. Limits broadcast domains and lateral movement.
Security model assuming no implicit trust. Verify every access request regardless of location. Never trust, always verify.
Network layer protocol responsible for addressing and routing packets across networks. IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses, IPv6 uses 128-bit.
Connection-oriented transport protocol ensuring reliable, ordered delivery. Establishes sessions, performs error checking, flow control.
Connectionless transport protocol for fast, lightweight communication. No reliability guarantees. Used for streaming, DNS, VoIP.
Application protocol for web communication. HTTPS adds TLS/SSL encryption for secure data transfer.
Protocol for transferring files between systems. FTP is insecure (plaintext). SFTP adds SSH encryption.
Protocol for sending email between servers. Works with POP3 or IMAP for receiving email.
System translating human-readable domain names to IP addresses. Hierarchical, distributed database. Critical internet infrastructure.
Protocol automatically assigning IP addresses and network configuration to devices. Simplifies network management.
Layer 3 device forwarding packets between networks based on IP addresses. Makes routing decisions, connects different networks.
Layer 2 device forwarding frames within network based on MAC addresses. Creates dedicated connections, segments collision domains.
Layer 1 device broadcasting data to all connected devices. No intelligence. Creates single collision domain. Largely obsolete.
Layer 2 device connecting network segments, filtering traffic based on MAC addresses. Reduces collision domains.
Device providing wireless network connectivity. Bridges wireless clients to wired network. Central point for WLAN.
Security device filtering traffic based on rules. Can be hardware or software. Controls traffic between network segments.
Intermediary server handling requests on behalf of clients. Provides caching, filtering, anonymity, and access control.
Device distributing network traffic across multiple servers. Improves availability, performance, and scalability.
Filters traffic based on headers (source/destination IP, port, protocol). Stateless. Fast but limited security. Layer 3-4.
Tracks connection state, understands context of traffic. More secure than packet filtering. Monitors TCP handshakes and sessions.
Operates at Layer 7, inspects application data. Deep packet inspection. Can filter based on URLs, content, applications.
Advanced firewall combining traditional filtering with IPS, application awareness, SSL inspection, threat intelligence.
Protects web applications from attacks like SQL injection, XSS, CSRF. Operates at HTTP/HTTPS level.
Single device combining multiple security functions: firewall, IPS, antivirus, content filtering, VPN. All-in-one security.
Passive monitoring system detecting suspicious activities and policy violations. Alerts administrators but doesn't block traffic.
Active system detecting and blocking malicious traffic in real-time. Inline deployment. Can impact performance.
Monitors network traffic at strategic points. Analyzes packets for known attack signatures and anomalies.
Monitors activities on individual systems. Examines logs, file integrity, system calls. Detects host-specific attacks.
Identifies threats by matching against known attack patterns. Fast and accurate for known threats. Ineffective against zero-days.
Identifies threats by detecting deviations from normal behavior baseline. Can detect unknown attacks but higher false positives.
Encrypted tunnel over public networks providing secure remote access or site-to-site connectivity. Protects data in transit.
Allows individual users to connect securely to corporate network from remote locations. Client-to-site connection.
Connects entire networks together over internet. Links branch offices to headquarters. Always-on connection between networks.
Suite of protocols encrypting and authenticating IP packets. Works at network layer. Used for VPNs. AH (authentication) and ESP (encryption).
VPN using SSL/TLS protocols. Browser-based, no special client needed. Works at transport/application layer. Easier deployment.
VPN configuration routing some traffic through VPN tunnel while other traffic goes directly to internet. Performance vs security tradeoff.
Network name identifying wireless network. Can be broadcast or hidden. Not a security feature despite common misconception.
Original WiFi encryption standard. Severely flawed and easily cracked. Should never be used. Obsolete.
Improved security replacing WEP. Uses TKIP encryption. Still vulnerable. Deprecated in favor of WPA2/WPA3.
Current standard using AES encryption. Personal (PSK) for home, Enterprise (802.1X) for business. KRACK vulnerability discovered.
Latest standard with improved security. Protects against brute force, provides forward secrecy. Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE).
Port-based network access control. Requires authentication before granting network access. Used in enterprise wireless and wired networks.
Unauthorized wireless access point on network. Security risk providing backdoor access. Must be detected and removed.
Malicious access point mimicking legitimate network. Tricks users into connecting. Intercepts traffic. Man-in-the-middle attack.
Attack overwhelming system with traffic to disrupt availability. Single source. Makes service unavailable to legitimate users.
DoS attack from multiple sources simultaneously. Uses botnets. Much harder to defend against than single-source DoS.
Attacker intercepts communications between two parties. Can eavesdrop or modify traffic. ARP spoofing, session hijacking.
Corrupting DNS cache with false information. Redirects users to malicious sites. Compromises DNS server or cache.
Sending fake ARP messages to associate attacker's MAC with victim's IP. Enables man-in-the-middle attacks on LANs.
Probing systems to discover open ports and services. Reconnaissance technique. Identifies potential attack vectors.
Capturing and analyzing network traffic. Legitimate for troubleshooting, malicious for stealing data. Promiscuous mode required.
Taking over authenticated session by stealing or predicting session tokens. Bypasses authentication.
Dividing network into security zones based on trust levels and requirements. Limits blast radius of breaches.
Layered security approach using multiple controls at different layers. If one fails, others still protect.
Granting minimum network access necessary. Applies to devices, services, and users. Reduces attack surface.
Turning off unnecessary network services and closing unused ports. Reduces attack surface and potential vulnerabilities.
Continuous observation of network traffic and device behavior. Detects anomalies, performance issues, security incidents.
Systematic process for updating network devices and systems with security patches. Closes known vulnerabilities.
Using robust encryption protocols for data in transit. TLS 1.2+, IPSec, WPA2/WPA3. Protects against eavesdropping.
Protocol for collecting and organizing information about network devices. Monitors health, performance, configuration.
Cisco technology capturing IP traffic information. Provides visibility into network usage patterns and anomalies.
Tool capturing and analyzing network packets. Wireshark, tcpdump. Used for troubleshooting and security analysis.
Hardware device copying network traffic for monitoring without affecting performance. Provides full visibility for security tools.
Switch feature copying traffic from one port to another for monitoring. Alternative to network tap using existing infrastructure.
Documented normal network behavior and performance metrics. Reference for detecting anomalies and measuring changes.
Controlling network traffic to optimize performance and prevent congestion. QoS, traffic shaping, rate limiting.

items.description: Connection-oriented. Reliable delivery with error checking, ordering, retransmission. Slower. Used for HTTP, FTP, email.
Connectionless. No reliability guarantees. Faster with less overhead. Used for DNS, streaming, VoIP, gaming.
TCP when accuracy matters (files, emails). UDP when speed matters and some loss acceptable (video, voice, DNS).
Layer 3 device. Routes between networks using IP addresses. Intelligent path selection. Connects different networks.
Layer 2 device. Forwards within network using MAC addresses. Creates dedicated connections. Segments collision domains.
Layer 1 device. Broadcasts to all ports. No intelligence. Single collision domain. Obsolete technology.
Passive monitoring. Detects and alerts on threats. Out-of-band deployment. Cannot stop attacks, only reports them.
Active protection. Detects and blocks threats. Inline deployment. Can stop attacks in real-time but may impact performance.
Tracks connection state and context. Understands sessions. More secure. Can make intelligent decisions based on traffic history.
Filters each packet independently. No context or memory. Faster but less secure. Simple packet filtering based on headers.
Monitors network traffic at strategic points. Protects entire network segment. Cannot see encrypted traffic or host activities.
Monitors individual systems. Sees encrypted traffic and local activities. More detailed but requires agent on each host.
Matches known attack patterns. Fast and accurate for known threats. Low false positives. Cannot detect zero-day attacks.
Detects deviations from normal baseline. Can find unknown threats. Higher false positives. Requires training period.
Network layer (Layer 3). Requires client software. More complex setup. Better for site-to-site. Encrypts all IP traffic.
Transport/Application layer. Browser-based, no client needed. Easier deployment. Better for remote access. Application-specific.

comparisons.title: Remote Access VPN vs Site-to-Site VPN

items.description: Individual users to network. Client-to-site. On-demand connection. Used by remote workers. End-user focused.
Network to network. Always-on connection. Connects branch offices. Gateway-to-gateway. Infrastructure focused.
Current standard. AES encryption. Vulnerable to KRACK attack and brute force. PSK and Enterprise modes available.
Latest standard. Enhanced security. Protects against brute force. Forward secrecy. SAE (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals).
Attack from single source. Easier to defend against. Can block single IP. Limited impact compared to DDoS.
Attack from multiple sources (botnet). Much harder to defend. Cannot simply block IPs. Massive scale possible.
Intermediary handling requests. Provides caching, content filtering, anonymity. Application-level gateway. Can modify traffic.
Security boundary filtering traffic. Enforces access policies. Network-level protection. Typically doesn't cache or modify content.
Layer 1. Broadcasts to all ports. No intelligence. Single collision domain. Half-duplex. Obsolete technology.
Layer 2. Forwards to specific port using MAC table. Intelligent. Separate collision domains. Full-duplex. Modern standard.
